repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Rural Primary Education
            Management, and Basic Education Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit differs from the
            Implementation Completion Report's (ICR) ratings
            regarding the Rural Primary Education Management Project, in
            that project outcomes are downgraded from satisfactory to
            unsatisfactory, and likewise regarding Bank and Borrower
            performance ratings; yet, sustainability is upgraded to
            likely, while institutional development impacts remain as
            modest. Conversely, on assessing the Basic Education Project
            (PROMEB), the audit concurs with the ICR's ratings of
            satisfactory outcomes, substantial institutional development
            impacts, likely sustainability, and satisfactory Bank and
            Borrower performances. Experience with the assessed
            projects, confirm a number of the Operations Evaluation
            Department - OED - lessons in the education sector: Despite
            considerable quality-oriented investments by both the
            assessed projects, progress in student performance has been
            limited, confirming that educational project inputs, and
            rising education budgets do not translate automatically into
            increased student performance; rather, to increase
            performance, teachers and students must use inputs
            effectively, maximizing the instructional time students are
            engaged in learning. While both assessed projects developed
            action plans, their implementation was limited. Such actions
            must be feasible within the budget, and human resources
            available, and, Government officials must also clearly
            perceive the need for plans, and the subsequent actions.
            Notwithstanding, the PROMEB and its follow-up project
            successfully involved the communities in the management of
            rural schools, which suggests that decentralization of
            school management to the community level, may mobilize local
            support for the schools, thus increasing pride in
            achievement by students, and teachers. However, although the
            achievement tests developed through PROMEB provided valuable
            monitoring information to the government, such outcomes were
            not widely disseminated, and its use was limited: to be
            valuable, however, the information must be disseminated
            widely at the school level if possible, and actions must be
            carried out based on the feedback it provides.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Basic Education Project's
            outcome is rated as satisfactory, sustainability as likely,
            institutional development impact as substantial, Bank
            performance as satisfactory, and Borrower performance as
            satisfactory. The most substantial impact on implementation
            was caused by hurricane Mitch in November 1998. To respond
            to the crisis, the project legal documents were amended in
            April 1999, thereby integrating the project in the national
            emergency plan through a new emergency subprojects
            component. This component was instrumental in providing
            resources at the departmental and community levels. The key
            lessons learned are: A community-based strategy can lead to
            rapid improvements in the delivery of education services in
            rural areas. The achievement of project development
            objectives is best guaranteed by appropriate adjustments to
            the changing needs of the country and the sector. The
            development impact of external evaluation of student
            learning achievements is greatly enhanced when results are
            broadly disseminated and utilized in sector policy
            decision-making. Maintenance agreements for the
            sustainability of education infrastructure must be supported
            by adequate financing. The production of textbooks and other
            education materials must be supported by an efficient
            distribution system. New textbooks should be consistent with
            changes in curriculum. The production of new education
            materials is enhanced by the systematic field test of such materials.

18155152.subsc: Tertiary education,Primary education,Pre-primary education,Central government administration
18155152.theme: Rural services and infrastructure,Education for all,Participation and civic engagement,Decentralization,Administrative and civil service reform
18155152.majtheme: Rural development,Human development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Public sector governance

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Basic Education
            Project are to improve the quality of learning and student
            performance, inspire better teaching, increase school
            attendance, and create more effective learning conditions,
            thereby reducing student dropout and repetition rates and
            raising student's academic achievements. The project
            also aims at strengthening the Ministry of Education's
            institutional capacity to deliver basic education services
            at higher levels of efficiency and fiscal accountability,
            leading to a reduction in administrative costs. The project
            comprises two major components. The first component is the
            Improving the Quality of Basic Education component which
            provides for: 1) training and assistance to upgrade the
            skills of preprimary and primary teachers, principals and
            supervisors, and improvements to pre-service teacher
            training and accreditation; 2) educational materials
            including textbooks, didactic materials, classroom
            libraries, and improved distribution facilities; 3)
            bilingual education in indigenous areas for the Garfuna and
            Miskito communities; 4) external evaluation of
            student's academic achievements; and 5) infrastructure
            improvements for overcrowded rural schools, including
            additional teachers and access to community-run preschool
            education in poor rural areas. The second component is an
            Institutional Strengthening one which will provide for: 1)
            technical assistance for the restructuring and
            decentralization of the MOE, and improved supervision; 2) a
            pilot program of teacher performance incentives; and 3)
            project administration, monitoring and evaluation.
